Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Forest Ecosystem Responses to Interacting Bark Beetle and Fire Disturbance are set up by Regeneration in the First Year
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past two decades, forests in the western US have experienced increases in bark beetle infestations and higher incidence of forest fires. The resulting tree mortality produces ecosystem responses that affect water quantity and quality, carbon storage, and nutrient cycling, with implications for future forest production and health. Understanding how these two stresses affect forests is critical to the management and availability of water in the western US. This award will significantly contribute to ecosystem models that predict where and how fast carbon, nitrogen and water move in these forests. Results from this study will be shared with regional water and forest managers using the Wyoming Water Forum. Underrepresented and first-generation pre-college students will be involved in the project through the University of Wyoming "Summer Research Apprentice Program".


This award will quantify carbon and water fluxes in relation to post-beetle fire intensity, partitioning these fluxes into contributions from the understory plants, overstory plants, and soil. The researchers will further assess the interactive effects between post-beetle fire and vegetation regrowth, specifically in regard to soil water and available soil N. The researchers will take advantage of a recent fire that burned through a beetle-affected lodgepole pine forest in Chimney Park Wyoming. The heterogeneous distribution of burn severity and existing pre-burn data provide a unique opportunity to understand the physical and biological processes that control the water, carbon, and nitrogen cycles within a forest ecosystem following sequential and interacting disturbances. The researchers will measure ecosystem pools and fluxes of carbon dioxide, water, and nitrogen in forest patches of different post-beetle burn intensities (bark beetles only, bark beetles plus understory fire, bark beetles and stand replacing fire) using eddy covariance, sap flow, electrical resistivity tomography, vegetation surveys, and biogeochemical techniques. This study will leverage existing equipment and benefits from an extensive pre-disturbance data set. This award will develop predictions and attribution to biological (e.g. transpiration controlled by plant conductance) and/or physical (e.g. soil evaporation and interception from bare branches) drivers in these forests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2003 to 2012, bark beetles accounted for 32% of observed tree mortality in the western United States forests. Inevitably, these beetle-affected forests will be subjected to wildfires in the future. Many of these forests will not yet have fully recovered from bark beetles by the time they are affected by fire. This interaction between the two disturbances (beetles and fire) has uncertain impacts on important ecosystem functions (e.g., water and carbon cycling) as well as the recovery of the forest. The main objective of this project was to monitor these ecosystem functions and vegetation recovery after a fire in a forest that was recently affected by bark beetles.

In the early summer of 2018, a wildfire burned more than 21,000 acres of previously beetle-affected lodgepole pine forest in southeastern Wyoming. The resulting landscape contained patches that were not affected by fire (NF), patches that were affected by an understory fire with surviving trees (UF), and patches in which a high-severity fire removed all living vegetation (SF). Located in this forest is the AmeriFlux Chimney Park (US-CPk) research site, which has been providing valuable vegetation and ecosystem data since 2008 – before the peak of the beetle outbreak in the early 2010s in the area. The fire damaged most of the instruments but also provided a unique opportunity to study the immediate impacts of post-beetle fire on ecosystem recovery.

In the first year of this project, we re-instrumented the site with various important sensors to monitor ecosystem functions and recovery, including sap flow sensors (tree-water use), time-lapse electrical resistivity tomography (deep soil moisture), five eddy covariance stations (atmospheric carbon and water dynamics), and over 140 soil sensors (shallow soil properties). We also sampled vegetation in 33 plots across all fire intensities in the area, including tree conditions (healthy without beetle evidence, beetle-affected but alive, beetle-dead, fire-dead) and understory regeneration, including tree seedlings and other plant growth. Soil and leaf samples from plots in all burn intensities were analyze regarding their carbon and nitrogen content and burned tree boles were collected and lab-tested for differences in burn characteristics between beetle-killed and healthy wood.

In 2019, during the first full summer after the fire, volumetric water content was 5-10% lower in unburned (NF) compared to the other stands in the upper 30 cm of soil, whereas at 50 cm depth all stands were similar. Water also infiltrated more rapidly and deeper in NF. Later in the season, the deeper soils of NF appear to dry more pervasively and to deeper depths than the soils in understory fire (UF) and severe fire (SF).

The above-canopy movement of water from the soil and plants into the air (i.e., evapotranspiration or “ET”) was similar between SF and NF from July to September. Below-canopy ET was greater in NF than UF for early and late summer. The release of CO2 from decomposition (i.e., respiration) in burned stands (UF & SF) was considerably lower than in unburned stands (NF). This is likely due to the lag of decomposable matter in UF and SF. Soil temperatures were consistently higher in SF and snow melt started three weeks earlier in SF compared to NF and UF. Foliar C content in first-year lodgepole pine seedlings was significantly higher in SF compared to those growing in UF whereas foliar N content was significantly lower in SF compared to UF. Charred remains of beetle-killed timber contain a higher proportion of biochar, a type of carbon that naturally decays very slowly, with important implications for carbon budget estimates of beetle-killed wildfires.

Our data allow for partitioning of the movement of water and carbon driven by abiotic (physical and chemical) and by biotic (vegetation and microbial) processes. This extensive dataset will be used to improve predictive models of carbon and water dynamics of ecosystems that in the future will be characterized by increasingly overlapping and interacting disturbance regimes.

This project provided support and training for 11 undergraduate students (two of whom have since been accepted to graduate programs; one Ph.D. and one M.S.), four graduate students (one of whom is now a post-doc). The project also provided educational opportunities for 11 undergraduate students as part of a summer field course at the site in 2019. Data from this project are made available via the AmeriFlux network to reach a broad audience of collaborators.
